conclusion: To determine the temperature in state B, use the ideal-gas equation pV = nRT at the two known states B and C.
State C: p≈5 ×10⁵ Pa, V≈2 ×10⁻³ m³
State B: p≈2 ×10⁵ Pa, V≈5 ×10⁻³ m³

premise: State C: p≈5 ×10⁵ Pa, V≈2 ×10⁻³ m³, T = 300 K
conclusion: Compute the amount of gas n from state C: n = pC VC / (R TC) = (5×10⁵ Pa)(2×10⁻³ m³) / (8.31 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 300 K) ≈ 0.40 mol

premise: State B: p≈2 ×10⁵ Pa, V≈5 ×10⁻³ m³, n ≈ 0.40 mol
conclusion: Use that same n for state B to find TB: TB = pB VB / (n R) = (2×10⁵ Pa)(5×10⁻³ m³) / (0.40 mol × 8.31 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹) ≈ 300 K
The gas temperature in state B is approximately 300 K.
